messageBody:
On Fri, 7 Nov 2003, Stirling, Scott wrote:

> > This class is related to the Java class, the file with the
> > .class extension, but it is not the same. Among other
> > things, it is much larger :-(
> [snip]
> > In other words, fixtures can include classes, although they
> > almost always consist only of objects.
>
> I think you're equivocating on the word 'class' here. Classes are
> always dealt programmatically in Java via the java.lang.Class object,
> or, if you're manipulating the constituent binary data, via an
> InputStream or some other object. I think you were right before, in
> the general sense: Java deals with objects except for the primitive
> types.

Uhm, yes...

If you look through the literature, you will find things called defining
class loaders. They are class loaders that turn byte arrays into classes.
JXCL acts as a defining class loader, using the method

protected final Class defineClass(String name, byte[] b, int off,
int len) throws ClassFormatError

to produce what you can see by inspecting the signature are in fact
genuine Java classes. If the byte array b is recognized by the JVM as
a Java class, it loads it, anointing it as such. If the JVM doesn't
find it acceptable, it throws the ClassFormatError.

Essentially, if the JVM says that a data structure is a Java class, it
is a Java class. It's loaded into a special area and treated in a
very special way.

Of course I accept that others use the word in a different sense in other
contexts. But here, in the Java context, a class can most certainly be
created by a program. If you wish, I can point you to countless
references. For starters, try Sheng Liang's "Dynamic Class Loading in
the Java Virtual Machine"; it's an easy read. There is a link from
http://java.sun.com/people/sl

Perhaps you would accept this formulation:

"A fixture is a non-empty set of objects and/or primitive types, which
are normally initialized before testing, except that in rare cases the
objects may be uninstantiated (and therefore uninitialized) Java
classes."
